pageContext.description:
The painting depicts Martin Luther as a half-length figure against a blue background. He is shown in three-quarter profile facing right and has been shifted slightly to the left, off the central axis of the panel. Luther wears a black gown with high collar over a black tunic, which has a red ribbon at the neck and reveals the black fringed collar of a white shirt. Luther's plump facial features are characterized by a five o'clock shadow; his short curly hair oscillates between dark and light shades of grey. 
[Görres, cda 2016]

pageContext.provenance:
[still in progress/research by our staff]
- C. Fairfax Murray, London
- Meta and Paul J. Sachs, to Fogg Art Museum, 1955
- The painting was transferred to the Busch-Reisinger collections (at Harvard) in 1965 under the number BR65.21. It returned to the Fogg under its original Fogg number on January 1, 1990.
[Harvard Art Museums/Fogg Museum, revised 2015]
pageContext.repository: Harvard Art Museums/Fogg Museum, Cambridge, Mass.

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
Support:
- the wooden panel is in sound condition
- cradled; covered with canvas and painted white on verso
- old vertical crack 1/3 from left
- strong convex warp 1 1/4" off the plane

Ground/Paint layers:
- inscription along the top edge. Underdrawing plainly visible.
- abrasion in vertical lines in center; some in neck
- old inpainting, slightly darkened  

Varnish:
- varnish is not yet yellowed; in very good condition

Frame:
- black molded frame with gilded liner - not the original, but appropriate
- the frame is in good condition

see also pdf

tests.text:
Frame bought from Doll & Richards in 1914 for $60
[Harvard Art Museums/Fogg Museum  2015]

pageContext.signature:
Artist's insignia above the sitter's proper right shoulder: winged serpent with dropped wings and dated '1546'; in black paint

[cda 2014]
